5. Quick start

Source: vignettes/quollr5quickstart.Rmd
quollr5quickstart.Rmd
library(quollr)
library(tibble)

In here, we use fit_highd_model() function to construct the model in 2D and high-dimensional space using the provided training data (s_curve_noise_training) and the precomputed scaled UMAP embeddings (s_curve_noise_umap_scaled). The function takes various parameters to configure the model construction process, such as the column names for the 2D embeddings (x and y), the number of bins (num_bins_x and num_bins_y), and other options for binning and hexagon visualization.

model <- fit_highd_model(training_data=s_curve_noise_training, 
                         nldr_df_with_id=s_curve_noise_umap_scaled, x = "UMAP1", 
                         y  = "UMAP2", num_bins_x = 4, num_bins_y = 7, 
                         x_start = -0.1732051, y_start = -0.15, buffer_x = 0.346, 
                         buffer_y = 0.3,  hex_size = 0.2, is_bin_centroid = TRUE, 
                         is_rm_lwd_hex = FALSE, 
                         col_start_2d = "UMAP", col_start_highd = "x")
## 2D model
glimpse(model$df_bin)
#> Rows: 10
#> Columns: 8
#> $ hb_id <int> 2, 5, 6, 10, 11, 15, 20, 23, 24, 28
#> $ x1    <dbl> -0.636602704, -0.498439940, 0.294457441, 0.309089774, 0.86761456…
#> $ x2    <dbl> 1.74398667, 0.52443695, 1.40452199, 0.04212599, 0.74730061, 1.26…
#> $ x3    <dbl> -1.7641833, -1.7303881, -1.8845346, -1.8325686, -0.7811911, -0.1…
#> $ x4    <dbl> 0.0095304602, -0.0002371844, 0.0088975133, 0.0065624927, -0.0040…
#> $ x5    <dbl> -0.0014349303, 0.0023416710, -0.0080267578, 0.0082266577, 0.0008…
#> $ x6    <dbl> -0.011690348, -0.029689934, -0.012337284, 0.004886255, 0.0248442…
#> $ x7    <dbl> -0.0015190610, -0.0002422371, -0.0012016197, -0.0038868552, 0.00…

## high-D model
glimpse(model$df_bin_centroids)
#> Rows: 10
#> Columns: 4
#> $ hexID      <int> 2, 5, 6, 10, 11, 15, 20, 23, 24, 28
#> $ c_x        <dbl> 1.732051e-01, -1.924311e-08, 3.464101e-01, 1.732051e-01, 5.…
#> $ c_y        <dbl> -0.15, 0.15, 0.15, 0.45, 0.45, 0.75, 1.05, 1.35, 1.35, 1.65
#> $ std_counts <dbl> 0.2352941, 0.5294118, 0.4117647, 0.1764706, 0.3529412, 0.70…
